In the ocean, plastic pollution causes irreparable damage to various aspects of ocean health and the marine ecosystem. To prevent further damage, it is essential to reduce the amount of macroplastics in the ocean. We propose a Graph Neural Network (GNN) based communication mechanism that increases the observation space of agents. In our custom environment, agents control a plastic-collecting vessel. The communication mechanism enables agents to develop a communication protocol using a binary signal. The goal of the agent collective is to clean up as much plastic as possible, while agents are rewarded for the individual amount of macroplastics collected. This encourages agents to learn effective communication while maintaining high individual performance. We compare our proposed communication mechanism with a multi-agent baseline without the ability to communicate. The results show that communication enables collaboration and significantly increases collective performance, indicating that agents have learned the importance of communication and found a balance between collaboration and competition.

Keywords: Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning, Graph Neural Network, Collaboration, Communication, Competition, Proximal Policy Optimization, Ocean Macroplastics.

Introduction:

Between 1950 and 2019, plastic production increased to 460 million tonnes per year (Ritchie & Roser, 2018). Approximately 12 million tonnes of plastic end up in the ocean (Stafford & Jones, 2019; Cressey, 2016; Eunomia, 2016). If the plastic production rate continues to rise, plastic will outweigh fish by 2050 (WEF, 2016). More than half of the plastic floating in the ocean, i.e., macroplastics, is less dense than water and does not sink to the ground (Lebreton et al., 2017). This means that the buoyant plastic mass is within the top meters of the ocean surface (Reisser et al., 2015; Kooi et al., 2016).

The presence of macroplastics in the ocean is harmful to marine life, humans, and the marine ecosystem. Around 800 coastal and marine species are directly affected by plastics in the ocean (Harding, 2016). 17% of the affected species are on the International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN) list of endangered species (Gall & Thompson, 2015). Animals are affected by various causes, including entanglement, ingestion, and the production of odors that attract animals.

Entanglement can restrict movement and feeding ability, causing infections and potentially leading to death (Fisheries, 2021). Animals ingest plastics, mistaking them for food, and microplastics can become entangled in algae and seaweed, producing an odor that attracts animals (Pfaller et al., 2020). Microplastics can resemble plankton, which is food for many species, and even small organisms like polyps living in corals consume microplastics (Rotjan et al., 2019). Annually, 100,000 marine mammals and a million seabirds die due to plastic waste (Martin, 2023). Humans also consume plastic toxins through seafood, which can be linked to hormonal abnormalities and developmental problems (Smith et al., 2018; Rochester, 2013).

The largest accumulation of garbage in the ocean is the Great Pacific Garbage Patch (GPGP), first discovered by Charles J. Moore in 1997. The GPGP measures an area three times the size of France, covering approximately 1.6 million square kilometers (Lebreton et al., 2018).

Contribution:

To clean up the GPGP, a company named The Ocean Cleanup utilized a fleet of 30 boats, 652 surface nets, and two flights. The size and dynamic properties of the GPGP make it an ideal use case for a highly distributed system, including multiple agents that have learned to take independent actions. We believe that efforts to clean up oceans and rivers can benefit from Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning (MARL) systems. However, for higher planning precision and efficiency, we believe a communication mechanism can contribute significantly. Our proposed system is inspired by the way animals communicate, such as a dog wagging its tail or an octopus changing color to signal an alert state. We propose a highly distributed MARL system with a dynamic GNN communication layer, allowing pairs of agents to observe the garbage density of simulated environments.
